'''Boyd Tyrone Herndon''' (born May 2, 1962) is an American [[country music]] singer and songwriter. His music career began in the 1980s as a member of the Tennessee River Boys, a predecessor to the country band [[Diamond Rio]]. Herndon quit the band early on and gained his first national exposure as a competitor on ''[[Star Search]]''. He then played at various [[honky-tonk]]s in [[Texas]]. After signing to [[Epic Records]] in 1993, Herndon made his debut in 1995 with his number-one single, "[[What Mattered Most (song)|What Mattered Most]]". This was followed that same year by the release of his first album, also titled ''[[What Mattered Most]]''.

Herndon released three more studio albums and a compilation for Epic: ''[[Living in a Moment]]'' (1996), ''[[Big Hopes]]'' (1998), ''[[Steam (Ty Herndon album)|Steam]]'' (1999), and ''[[This Is Ty Herndon: Greatest Hits]]'' (2002). He recorded a Christmas album in 2002 before a recording hiatus. He returned with his fifth studio album, ''[[Right About Now (Ty Herndon album)|Right About Now]]'' (2007) for the Titan Pyramid label; his sixth studio release, ''Journey On'', followed in 2010. Herndon has charted a total of 17 singles on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts. This figure includes three number-ones: "What Mattered Most", "[[Living in a Moment (song)|Living in a Moment]]" and "[[It Must Be Love (Ty Herndon song)|It Must Be Love]]". His singles "[[I Want My Goodbye Back]]", "[[Loved Too Much]]", "[[A Man Holdin' On (To a Woman Lettin' Go)]]", and "[[Hands of a Working Man]]" all made top ten on the same chart.

Herndon gained further media attention in 2014 after he [[coming out|came out]] as gay, becoming the first mainstream male country music singer to do so. His personal life has been the subject of mainstream media for other reasons, including his struggles with drug addiction and mental health. His musical style is defined by his singing voice and an emphasis on ballads.

== Early life ==
Boyd Tyrone Herndon was born on May 2, 1962, in [[Meridian, Mississippi]], to Boyd and Renee Herndon.<ref name="allmusic"/><ref name="facts">{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/322684326/ | title=Ty Herndon: the facts of life | work=The Tribune | date=August 19, 1997 | access-date=June 18, 2022 | pages=3}}</ref> He was raised just across the state line in [[Butler, Alabama]].<ref name="allmusic">{{cite web |url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p142392|pure_url=yes}} |title=Ty Herndon biography |access-date=May 15, 2008 |last=Erlewine |first=Stephen Thomas |author-link=Stephen Thomas Erlewine |publisher=[[AllMusic]]}}</ref> His grandmother played guitar and hosted her own radio show in Butler.<ref name="facts"/> He became involved in music in his youth. Herndon's first performance on a stage came during this period, when he won $75 at a talent show in [[Toxey, Alabama]].<ref name="facts"/>

[[File:Diamond Rio USAF.jpg|200px|thumb|left|Herndon was a founding member of the Tennessee River Boys, who later became [[Diamond Rio]] (pictured here in 2006).|alt=Country music band Diamond Rio performing onstage.]]

Shortly after graduating from [[Austin High School (Alabama)|Austin High School]] in [[Decatur, Alabama]], Herndon moved to [[Nashville, Tennessee]], to pursue a career in country music.<ref name="allmusic"/> At this point he also attended [[Belmont University]].<ref name="encyclopedia"/> Herndon's first major role came in 1983 when he became lead vocalist of the  Tennessee River Boys, a group that performed at the [[Opryland USA]] theme park in Nashville.<ref name="rio"/> This band was originally intended to perform a one-time show to promote the park, but became one of several regular performers there. Herndon left the band after only a year to become a contestant on the television talent show ''[[Star Search]]''.<ref name="rio">{{cite book
|author = Diamond Rio
 |author2=Tom Roland
|title     = Beautiful Mess: The Story of Diamond Rio
|year      = 2009
|publisher = Tyde Pod Publishers
|page=14
|isbn      = 978-1595552686}}</ref> Following Herndon's departure, the Tennessee River Boys underwent a number of membership changes and became [[Diamond Rio]].<ref name="rio"/> When his tenure on ''Star Search'' proved commercially unsuccessful, Herndon attempted to secure a recording contract in Nashville. He told ''[[The Tennessean]]'' in 1995 that multiple labels rejected him as they considered him a "pretty boy". Despite this, he found work singing [[jingle]]s for [[Pepsi]] and [[Dodge]], as well as [[demo (music)|demo]] tracks for other artists. He lost a significant amount of money due to an unfavorable management deal, which led to his mother having to sell her house in order to refinance the amount of money lost. In addition, Herndon's father died of a brain hemorrhage, putting further strain on both him and his family.<ref name="pretty">{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/112501036/ | title=A matter of time: Country's Ty Herndon goes from 'pretty boy' to hit maker | work=[[The Tennessean]] | date=May 22, 1995 | access-date=June 18, 2022 | author=[[Robert K. Oermann]] | pages=1, 2}}</ref>

Herndon then moved to [[Texas]] and found work performing in various [[honky-tonk]]s across the state, in order to regain some of the money he had lost.<ref name="encyclopedia"/><ref name="allmusic"/> His tenure in Texas included a stint with [[Louise Mandrell]] in 1987 at [[Billy Bob's Texas]], a country music [[nightclub]] in [[Fort Worth, Texas|Fort Worth]].<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/640386927/ | title=Nightlife: Fort Worth | work=[[Fort Worth Star-Telegram]] | date=September 25, 1987 | access-date=June 18, 2022 | pages=20}}</ref> He competed on another television talent show titled ''[[You Write the Songs]]'' in 1987, but was unsuccessful. Herndon also appeared on ''The Porter Wagoner Show'', a musical variety show hosted by country singer [[Porter Wagoner]].<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/764562580/ | title='Star Search' finalist Herndon sings at Junction | work=[[Abilene Reporter-News]] | date=June 17, 1988 | access-date=June 18, 2022 | pages=10B}}</ref> By 1989 he had formed a backing band called Bayou. This act opened for [[Little Texas (band)|Little Texas]] in 1989 prior to that band's signing with [[Warner Records]].<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/641571564/ | title=West side preview | work=Fort Worth Star-Telegram | date=September 27, 1989 | access-date=June 18, 2022 | pages=1–3}}</ref> In 1993, Herndon won a local music award called Texas Entertainer of the Year.<ref name="virgin">{{cite book | title=The Virgin Encyclopedia of Country Music | publisher=Virgin Books | author=[[Colin Larkin]] | year=1999 | location=London, England | pages=197}}</ref> At the awards ceremony, Herndon was discovered by a representative of [[Epic Records]], and he signed with the label later in the year.<ref name="facts"/>

== Career ==
=== 1995–96: ''What Mattered Most'' ===
Herndon began recording music for Epic in 1994.<ref name="pretty"/> He made his debut in early 1995 with the single "[[What Mattered Most (song)|What Mattered Most]]", a song written by [[Gary Burr]] and [[Vince Melamed]].<ref name="whitburn"/> The song went to number one on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts in the United States and the former ''[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]'' country music charts in Canada.<ref name="whitburn"/><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bac-lac.gc.ca/eng/discover/films-videos-sound-recordings/rpm/Pages/image.aspx?Image=nlc008388.9245&URLjpg=http%3a%2f%2fwww.collectionscanada.gc.ca%2fobj%2f028020%2ff4%2fnlc008388.9245.gif&Ecopy=nlc008388.9245 | title=RPM Country Tracks | publisher=RPM | work=[[Library and Archives Canada]] | date=May 22, 1995 | access-date=September 24, 2022}}</ref> Follow-up single "[[I Want My Goodbye Back]]" reached a Hot Country Songs peak of number seven in 1995.<ref name="whitburn"/> Its [[b-side]], a duet with [[Stephanie Bentley]] titled "[[Heart Half Empty]]", peaked at number 21 in early 1996.<ref name="whitburn">Whitburn 2017, p. 163</ref> "In Your Face" was the last single from ''What Mattered Most''. This song was the least successful, charting for only two weeks and reaching number 63.<ref name="whitburn"/>

The album featured backing vocals from several artists on Epic or sister label [[Columbia Records]], including [[Patty Loveless]], [[Joe Diffie]], [[Ron Wallace (singer)|Ron Wallace]], and [[Gibson/Miller Band]] member Blue Miller.<ref name="pretty"/><ref>{{cite AV media notes |title=What Mattered Most |others=Ty Herndon |year=1995 |publisher=Epic Records |id=66397}}</ref> [[Doug Johnson (record producer)|Doug Johnson]], then the vice-president of [[artists and repertoire]] (A&R) of Epic's Nashville branch, produced the album and co-wrote "I Want My Goodbye Back".<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/319107046/ | title=Country Jam USA | work=The Country Today | date=June 5, 1996 | access-date=June 18, 2022 | pages=19}}</ref> In addition to the singles, ''What Mattered Most'' included a cover of [[Jim Croce]]'s "[[You Don't Mess Around with Jim (song)|You Don't Mess Around with Jim]]".<ref name="mccall"/> Another track, the [[Vince Gill]] and [[Don Schlitz]] composition "You Just Get One", was later recorded by [[Jeff Wood (singer)|Jeff Wood]] on his 1997 album ''[[Between the Earth and the Stars (Jeff Wood album)|Between the Earth and the Stars]]''.<ref name="mccall"/><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/between-the-earth-and-the-stars-mw0000084272 | title=''Between the Earth and the Stars'' | publisher=AllMusic | access-date=June 18, 2022 | author=Jack Leaver}}</ref> Wood's rendition charted on Hot Country Songs that same year.<ref>Whitburn 2017, p. 405</ref> "Heart Half Empty" later appeared on Bentley's 1996 album ''[[Hopechest]]'', also issued on Epic.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/hopechest-mw0000179208 | title=''Hopechest'' | publisher=AllMusic | access-date=June 18, 2022}}</ref> The [[music video]] for "What Mattered Most" was aired on [[CMT (American TV channel)|CMT]] and the former TNN ([[The Nashville Network]]). Herndon promoted the album further by starting a tour in 1995.<ref name="debut">{{cite magazine | url=https://worldradiohistory.com/Archive-All-Music/Billboard/90s/1995/BB-1995-05-20.pdf | title=Herndon's Sony debut shows what matters | magazine=Billboard | pages=1, 101 | date=May 20, 1995}}</ref>

[[File:Tyherndon.jpg|200px|thumb|left|Herndon at the 2009 Point of Hope Fundraiser pre-party.|alt=Singer Ty Herndon standing in front of a fireplace.]]

Michael McCall of ''New Country'' magazine rated the album three-and-a-half stars out of five, as he considered Herndon's vocal delivery "confident" but was more mixed toward the lyrical content of the songs.<ref name="mccall">{{cite journal|last=McCall|first=Michael|title=Ty Herndon — ''What Mattered Most''|journal=New Country|volume=2|issue=7|page=62}}</ref> An uncredited review published by ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' was favorable, stating, "With a rich, expressive voice that is equally suited to pensive ballads and rollicking, uptempo tunes, Herndon is one of country's most impressive newcomers."<ref>{{cite magazine|date=June 24, 1995|title=Reviews|magazine=Billboard|page=62|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zwsEAAAAMBAJ&dq=%22ty+herndon%22+%22what+mattered+most%22+%22Review%22&pg=PA62}}</ref> In early 1997, ''What Mattered Most'' was certified gold by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA) for shipments of 500,000 copies.<ref name="riaa">{{cite web | url=https://www.riaa.com/gold-platinum/?tab_active=default-award&se=ty+herndon#search_section | title=Search results for Ty Herndon | publisher=[[Recording Industry Association of America]] | access-date=June 18, 2022}}</ref> Executives of [[Sony Music Nashville]], of which Epic was a division at the time, attributed the album's commercial success to a marketing strategy they employed at the time. Under this plan, albums by new artists were priced a dollar lower than the national average for sixty days after their release. These same executives also noted this strategy had been successful on albums by [[Wade Hayes]] and [[James House (singer)|James House]].<ref name="debut"/>

===1996{{ndash}}1997: ''Living in a Moment''===
In 1996, Herndon won the Male Star of Tomorrow, a fan-voted award from the TNN Music City News awards (now known as [[CMT Music Awards]]).<ref name="encyclopedia"/> His second album ''[[Living in a Moment]]'' was released in August of the same year.<ref name="allmusic"/> The album's lead single "[[Living in a Moment (song)|Living in a Moment]]" reached number one on the country charts in both the US and Canada.<ref name="whitburn"/><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bac-lac.gc.ca/eng/discover/films-videos-sound-recordings/rpm/Pages/image.aspx?Image=nlc008388.7758&URLjpg=http%3a%2f%2fwww.collectionscanada.gc.ca%2fobj%2f028020%2ff4%2fnlc008388.7758.gif&Ecopy=nlc008388.7758 | title=RPM Country Tracks | publisher=RPM | work=Library and Archives Canada | date=September 30, 1996 | access-date=September 24, 2022}}</ref> Three more singles charted from the album throughout 1997. The first was "[[She Wants to Be Wanted Again]]", which peaked at number 21 early in the year.<ref name="whitburn"/> This song had been recorded by [[Lee Greenwood]], [[Restless Heart]] vocalist [[Larry Stewart (singer)|Larry Stewart]], and [[Western Flyer]] prior to Herndon's rendition.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/loves-on-the-way-mw0000082127 | title=''Love's on the Way'' | publisher=AllMusic | access-date=June 19, 2022}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/heart-like-a-hurricane-mw0000626632 | title=''Heart Like a Hurricane'' | publisher=AllMusic | access-date=June 19, 2022}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/back-in-america-mw0000053827 | title=''Back in America'' | publisher=AllMusic | access-date=June 19, 2022}}</ref> After "She Wants to Be Wanted Again" came the number two hit "[[Loved Too Much]]" and the top-twenty "[[I Have to Surrender]]". Johnson co-wrote "Living in a Moment" and "I Have to Surrender",<ref name="whitburn"/> and once again served as producer. Stephanie Bentley, Blue Miller, and [[John Wesley Ryles]] were among the album's backing vocalists. Also contributing in this capacity were Doug Virden and Drew Womack, then recording on Epic in [[Sons of the Desert (band)|Sons of the Desert]].<ref>{{cite AV media notes |title=Living in a Moment |others=Ty Herndon |year=1996 |publisher=Epic Records |id=67564}}<</ref> Thom Owens of [[Allmusic]] wrote, "Although he is in fine voice throughout the album, Ty Herndon's ''Living in a Moment'' is bogged down by mediocre material that fails to given him a proper showcase for his talents."<ref name="herndon moment"/> He considered the title track and "Don't Tell Mama" the strongest lyrically.<ref name="herndon moment">{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/living-in-a-moment-mw0000189342 | title=''Living in a Moment'' review | publisher=AllMusic | access-date=June 18, 2022 | author=Thom Owens}}</ref> [[Alanna Nash]] of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' similarly thought "Don't Tell Mama" was the strongest track, but criticized the rest of the album as "formulaic".<ref name="ew moment">{{cite web | url=https://ew.com/article/1996/08/23/living-moment/ | title=Living in a Moment | publisher=[[Entertainment Weekly]] | date=August 23, 1996 | access-date=June 18, 2022}}</ref> [[Colin Larkin]] of the ''Virgin Encyclopedia of Country Music'' thought this album had "a shortage of standout material".<ref name="virgin"/> The album's closing track "[[I Know How the River Feels]]" was later a single in 1999 for Diamond Rio.<ref name="herndon moment"/><ref>Whitburn 2017, pp. 108-109</ref> ''Living in a Moment'' was also certified gold in 1997.<ref name="riaa"/>

===1998{{ndash}}2000: ''Big Hopes'' and ''Steam''===
''[[Big Hopes]]'', Herndon's third album, followed in 1998.<ref name="allmusic"/> Doug Johnson produced five of the tracks and [[Byron Gallimore]], best known for his work with [[Tim McGraw]], produced the other six.<ref name="cst big hopes">{{cite web | url=https://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/cdreview.asp?xid=2835 | title=''Big Hopes'' | publisher=[[Country Standard Time]] | access-date=June 18, 2022 | author=Walter Allread}}</ref> Herndon told the ''[[Journal & Courier]]'' that he considered Gallimore to have a more "understated" production style that put greater emphasis on his vocals than Johnson's production did.<ref name="rock">{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/265052379/ | title=Ty Herndon finds time to rock with 'Big Hopes' | work=[[Journal & Courier]] | date=May 7, 1999 | access-date=June 19, 2022 | pages=3}}</ref> Lead single "[[A Man Holdin' On (To a Woman Lettin' Go)]]", one of the tracks produced by Gallimore, was a top-five country hit that same year.<ref name="whitburn"/> After it came Herndon's third and final number-one single "[[It Must Be Love (Ty Herndon song)|It Must Be Love]]", which also became his only top-40 hit on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]].<ref name="whitburn"/> The song featured uncredited backing vocals from Sons of the Desert.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1021387/sons-of-the-desert-make-change-after-song-dispute/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171225091832/http://www.mtv.com/news/1021387/sons-of-the-desert-make-change-after-song-dispute/|url-status=dead|archive-date=December 25, 2017|title=SONS OF THE DESERT MAKE CHANGE AFTER SONG DISPUTE|last=Schmitzer|first=Lauren|date=June 14, 2000|publisher=MTV|access-date=June 4, 2017}}</ref> Jack Sundrud, formerly of [[Poco (band)|Poco]], had co-written "It Must Be Love" for [[Great Plains (Tennessee band)|Great Plains]], another band he was a member of at the time. When they did not record the song, it became available for Herndon.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/113474562/ | title='It Must Be' another hit for Ty Herndon | work=[[The Tennessean]] | date=October 25, 1998 | access-date=March 21, 2020 | pages=11K}}</ref> "[[Hands of a Working Man]]" was also a top-five country hit from ''Big Hopes''.<ref name="whitburn"/> Walter Allread of [[Country Standard Time]] thought that the tracks produced by Gallimore, such as the title track, were stronger due to their "smaller" production style relative to those produced by Johnson.<ref name="cst big hopes"/> Thom Owens of AllMusic was mixed toward the album, as he thought that it had "filler" tracks and "glossy production", although he praised Herndon's singing on "A Man Holdin' On" and "Hands of a Working Man".<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/big-hopes-mw0000036585 | title=''Big Hopes'' review | publisher=AllMusic | access-date=June 18, 2022 | author=Thom Owens}}</ref> Uncredited reviews of "A Man Holdin' On" and "Hands of a Working Man" in ''Billboard'' were both favorable. The former was praised for Gallimore's production and the "unique perspective...of men in difficult transitions",<ref>{{cite magazine | url=https://worldradiohistory.com/Archive-All-Music/Billboard/90s/1998/BB-1998-03-21.pdf | title=Single reviews | magazine=Billboard | pages=98 | date=March 21, 1998}}</ref> while the latter was described as being appealing to [[working class]] listeners due to its lyrical focus on a father's struggles.<ref>{{cite magazine | url=https://worldradiohistory.com/Archive-All-Music/Billboard/90s/1998/BB-1998-12-19.pdf | title=Single reviews | magazine=Billboard | pages=21 | date=December 19, 1998}}</ref>

In 1999, Epic released his next studio album ''[[Steam (Ty Herndon album)|Steam]]''.<ref name="allmusic"/> Herndon selected a new producer for this album, as he thought his previous albums did not reflect the energy of his live performances. He chose [[Joe Scaife]] because of that producer's work with [[K.T. Oslin]], a 1980s country artist Herndon referred to as "one of [his] all-time favorites".<ref name="ephrata">{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/743084163/ | title=Singer Ty Herndon headlines Reinholds carnival | work=The Ephrata Review | date=June 21, 2000 | access-date=June 18, 2022 | pages=A9, A11}}</ref> Herndon selected the songs for the album by performing them in concert so he and Scaife could gauge the audience's reaction to each. In addition, Herndon recorded demos with his road band, which he then played for the album's [[session musician]]s to give them an idea of how he wanted each song to sound.<ref name="ephrata"/> Among the involved musicians were drummer [[Paul Leim]], [[steel guitar]] player [[Dan Dugmore]], and guitarist Chris Leuzinger of [[Garth Brooks]]' studio band The G-Men. The album also included a [[horn section]] fronted by [[Jim Horn]], and a [[string section]] including members of the [[Nashville String Machine]].<ref>{{Cite AV media notes |title=Steam |others=Ty Herndon |year=1999 |type=CD booklet |publisher=Epic Records |id=69899}}</ref> "[[Steam (Ty Herndon song)|Steam]]", the album's title track, was also its lead single. It reached top twenty by the end of 1999, but was less successful than the lead singles of Herndon's previous albums.<ref name="whitburn"/> Two other singles, "[[No Mercy (Ty Herndon song)|No Mercy]]" and "A Love Like That", peaked even lower.<ref name="whitburn"/>

[[File:Joe Cocker - Festival du Bout du Monde 2013 - 017.jpg|150px|thumb|right|Herndon's 1999 album ''Steam'' included a cover of "[[You Can Leave Your Hat On]]", made famous by [[Joe Cocker]].|alt=English musician Joe Cocker, standing before a microphone.]]

Also included on the album was a cover of [[Joe Cocker]]'s "[[You Can Leave Your Hat On]]", which Herndon had sung in concert for many years prior.<ref name="ephrata"/> While not a single, the cover charted at number 72 on Hot Country Songs in 2000 due to unsolicited radio airplay.<ref name="whitburn"/> Herndon considered the album more "sexy" than his previous efforts, citing both this cover and the title track as examples.<ref name="ephrata"/> Dan MacIntosh of Country Standard Time considered Herndon "too darn polite" for such material, also criticizing the album for "by-the-numbers" arrangements.<ref name="cst steam">{{cite web | url=https://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/cdreview.asp?xid=2834 | title=''Steam'' review | publisher=Country Standard Time | access-date=June 18, 2022 | author=Dan MacIntosh}}</ref> A more favorable review came from AllMusic, whose Maria Konicki Dinoia wrote, "With a new production team in tow, Herndon has played a bigger part in selecting the album's songs...and it's clear he sings from the heart, as he always has."<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/steam-mw0000251942 | title=''Steam'' review | publisher=AllMusic | access-date=June 18, 2022 | author=Maria Konicki Dinoia}}</ref> Deborah Evans Price of ''Billboard'' found both "Steam" and "No Mercy" "equally sensuous" in a review of the latter.<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Price|first=Deborah Evans|date=January 8, 2000|title=Singles|magazine=Billboard|pages=20–21|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kw0EAAAAMBAJ&q=%22love%27s+the+only+house%22+%22harmonica%22&pg=PA20}}</ref>

===2001{{ndash}}2004: Departure from Epic Records===
In late 2001, Epic released the song "[[Heather's Wall]]", which was intended to be the lead single from Herndon's fifth album for the label. At the time, Herndon was considering exiting the music business to star in a [[Broadway theatre]] production of ''[[Urban Cowboy]]'', but decided against it. [[Paul Worley]], the producer with whom he was working at the time, recommended "Heather's Wall" to him when the two were selecting songs. Herndon originally rejected the song as "too heavy", but decided to record it after the [[September 11 attacks]] inspired him to record music again.<ref name="heather">{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1452185/ty-herndons-comeback-hanging-on-heathers-wall/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151129232713/http://www.cmt.com/news/1452185/ty-herndons-comeback-hanging-on-heathers-wall/|url-status=dead|archive-date=November 29, 2015|title=Ty Herndon's Comeback Hanging on "Heather's Wall"|last=Morris|first=Edward|date=February 6, 2002|work=[[CMT (U.S. TV channel)|CMT]]|access-date=31 January 2017}}</ref> Although the song was well-received by fans,<ref name="heather"/> it was unsuccessful on the singles charts and his fifth Epic album was not released.<ref name="whitburn"/><ref name="allmusic"/> Epic then released a greatest hits package titled ''[[This Is Ty Herndon: Greatest Hits]]'' before dropping him from the label.<ref name="allmusic"/> Herndon released a Christmas album, ''A Not So Silent Night,'' in 2002 through his fan club and official website. A year later, the Christmas album was repackaged with additional content and released on the independent label Riviera/Liquid8 Records.<ref name="allmusic"/> Otherwise, he took a hiatus from recording at this point due to a number of personal issues that included weight gain, divorce, and drug and alcohol addiction.<ref name="gactv.com"/>

===2004{{ndash}}2010: ''Right About Now'' and ''Journey On''===
He returned to touring and singing in 2004 when songwriter [[Darrell Brown (musician)|Darrell Brown]] invited him to perform at the Nashville nightclub [[Bluebird Café]].<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/631053671/ | title=Ty Herndon update | work=[[The Charlotte Observer]] | date=August 22, 2004 | access-date=June 18, 2022 | pages=2H}}</ref><ref name="gactv.com"/> This led to him signing with Titan Pyramid Records in 2006 and releasing the album ''[[Right About Now (Ty Herndon album)|Right About Now]]'' in early 2007.<ref name="allmusic"/> Brown and Herndon co-produced the album with songwriter Dennis Matkosky and session musician [[Jonathan Yudkin]]. Backing vocalists included [[Marcus Hummon]], [[Joanna Cotten]], [[Emily West]], and [[Thompson Square]].<ref>{{Cite AV media notes |title=Right About Now |others=Ty Herndon |year=2006 |type=CD booklet |publisher=Titan Records}}</ref> Thom Jurek of AllMusic reviewed the album favorably, stating that "Herndon's voice is not only unchanged from his missing years, it's stronger, his phrasing is tighter and more expressive, and his manner of handling a song is entirely his own."<ref name="allmusic right">{{cite web | url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/right-about-now-mw0000558835 | title=''Right About Now'' review | publisher=AllMusic | access-date=June 18, 2022 | author=Thom Jurek}}</ref> One track from this album was a cover of [[Johnny Reid]]'s "[[You Still Own Me]]", itself later a single in late 2007 for Canadian country band [[Emerson Drive]].<ref name="allmusic right"/><ref>Whitburn 2017, p. 120</ref>

Herndon's next album was ''Journey On'', released on the independent FUNL label in 2010.<ref name="allmusic"/> The album featured mostly [[contemporary Christian music]] songs, all of which Herndon wrote or co-wrote over the span of six months. Herndon said that he did not intend for the album to be a Christian project, but found that as he was writing, many of the songs tended toward reflecting his "spiritual growth". He also said that he found the album "fun" because of how much control he had over assembling musicians and recording compared to his previous releases.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/683543775/ | title=New CD takes Herndon on songwriting 'Journey' | work=[[The Macon Telegraph]] | date=May 21, 2010 | access-date=June 18, 2022 | author=Rachel Sullivan | pages=1E}}</ref> The album was nominated at the [[53rd Grammy Awards]] for [[Grammy Award for Best Southern, Country or Bluegrass Gospel Album]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.grammy.com/artists/ty-herndon/9076 | title=Search results for Ty Herndon | publisher=Grammy.com | access-date=June 18, 2022}}</ref> "Journey On" was selected by American football player [[Kevin Turner (running back)|Kevin Turner]] as the theme song for his Kevin Turner Foundation. This foundation is dedicated to research of [[amyotrophic lateral sclerosis]] or Lou Gehrig's Disease, which Turner had been recently diagnosed with at the time.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.countrystandardtime.com/news/newsitem.asp?xid=4855 | title=Journey continues for Ty Herndon | publisher=Country Standard Time | date=December 16, 2010 | access-date=June 18, 2022}}</ref> After ''Journey On'', he released a non-album single titled "Stones", which was previously recorded for his unreleased Epic album in 2001. FUNL released the song to country radio without disclosing the artist's name, and held a contest with radio programmers to see if they could determine the singer.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/ty-herndon-drops-stones-in-return-to-country-music-511217/ | title=Ty Herndon Drops 'Stones' in Return to Country Music | publisher=Billboard | date=January 17, 2012 | access-date=June 18, 2022 | author=Chuck Dauphin}}</ref>

===2013{{ndash}}present: ''Lies I Told Myself'', ''House on Fire'', ''Got It Covered''. and ''Jacob''===
The album ''Lies I Told Myself'' followed in 2013, also on FUNL. Prior to the album's release, Herndon had performed the title track in concert, and chose to make it the lead single due to its positive reception from fans. He also noted that the track "Beautiful Love Song" had been written eight years prior and rejected by other artists, but he chose to record it because he liked the sound of the song's demo. Another track on the album, "Sugar", was co-written by country singer [[Sara Evans]]'s brother, Matt Evans. Herndon compared this track to "Steam", and cited it as an example of the more "modern" sound he wanted on ''Lies I Told Myself''.<ref name="dauphin">{{cite web | url=https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/ty-herndon-returns-with-lies-i-told-myself-5762959/ | title=Ty Herndon Returns With 'Lies I Told Myself' | publisher=Billboard | date=October 17, 2013 | access-date=June 18, 2022 | author=[[Chuck Dauphin]]}}</ref> Herndon financed the album through a [[Kickstarter]] campaign,<ref name="opry">{{cite web | url=https://www.opry.com/artists/ty-herndon/ | title=Ty Herndon | publisher=[[Grand Ole Opry]] | access-date=June 18, 2022}}</ref> and supported it by touring with [[Jamie O'Neal]] and [[Andy Griggs]].<ref name="proud"/> Matt Bjorke of Roughstock reviewed the album favorably, praising Herndon's vocals on the ballads in particular.<ref name="lies">{{cite web | url=http://roughstock.com/news/2013/10/13877-album-review-ty-herndon-lies-i-told-myself | title=Album Review: Ty Herndon{{emdash}}''Lies I Told Myself'' | publisher=Roughstock | date=October 25, 2013 | access-date=June 18, 2022}}</ref>

His next album was 2016's ''House on Fire'', which once again featured several songs he co-wrote. It was his first release on the BFD label, and he co-produced with Drew Davis and Erik Halbig, a guitarist in Herndon's road band.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://tasteofcountry.com/ty-herndon-new-album-house-on-fire/ | title=Ty Herndon announces new album, 'House on Fire' | publisher=[[Taste of Country]] | date=September 20, 2016 | access-date=June 18, 2022 | author=Laura McClellan}}</ref><ref name="embraces">{{cite web | url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1773849/ty-herndon-embraces-life-with-new-album-house-on-fire/ | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161123143734/http://www.cmt.com/news/1773849/ty-herndon-embraces-life-with-new-album-house-on-fire/ | url-status=dead | archive-date=November 23, 2016 | title=Ty Herndon Embraces Life With New Album, House on Fire | publisher=CMT | date=November 21, 2016 | access-date=June 18, 2022}}</ref> Herndon described the title track as autobiographical, while in comparison, "All Night Tonight" came from Davis and Halbig wanting to write a "beach song".<ref name="embraces"/> This was followed in 2019 by ''Got It Covered'', which featured re-recordings of his hit singles along with [[cover song]]s. Among the songs covered were [[Marc Cohn]]'s "[[Walking in Memphis]]", [[Carrie Underwood]]'s "[[So Small]]", and [[Bonnie Raitt]]'s "[[I Can't Make You Love Me]]".<ref name="freeman">{{cite web | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/ty-herndon-covers-carrie-underwood-new-album-got-it-covered-lgbtq-activism-876268/ | title=Ty Herndon on Covering Carrie Underwood, LGBTQ Activism | publisher=[[Rolling Stone]] | date=August 26, 2019 | access-date=June 18, 2022 | author=Jon Freeman}}</ref> Herndon said that he had almost considered retiring from country music due to the lack of success of his last few albums until he heard "So Small" on the radio. When Underwood found that Herndon had covered the song, she spoke favorably about it on social media.<ref name="small">{{cite web | url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1810619/the-game-changing-message-carrie-underwood-had-for-ty-herndon/ | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190819195156/http://www.cmt.com/news/1810619/the-game-changing-message-carrie-underwood-had-for-ty-herndon/ | url-status=dead | archive-date=August 19, 2019 | title=The Game-Changing Message Carrie Underwood Had for Ty Herndon | publisher=CMT | date=August 19, 2019 | access-date=June 18, 2022 | author=Alison Bonaguro}}</ref> In 2020, Herndon collaborated with [[Kristin Chenoweth]] and [[Paul Cardall]] on a single titled "Orphans of God".<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.wnypapers.com/news/article/current/2020/10/23/143855/ty-herndon-kristin-chenoweth-release-new-duet-orphans-of-god | title=Ty Herndon + Kristin Chenoweth release new duet, 'Orphans of God' | publisher=WNY Papers | date=October 23, 2020 | access-date=September 24, 2022}}</ref>

Herndon's next single release was "Till You Get There" in June 2022 on Pivotal Records.<ref name="disc">{{cite web | url=https://musicrow.com/2022/06/disclaimer-single-reviews-ty-herndon-gives-radio-ready-performance-on-till-you-get-there/ | title=DISClaimer Single Reviews: Ty Herndon Gives Radio Ready Performance On 'Till You Get There' | publisher=[[MusicRow]] | date=June 2, 2022 | access-date=June 18, 2022 | author=Robert K. Oermann}}</ref> This was the lead single to his next studio album ''Jacob'', released one month later. It included more songs that Herndon had written about his personal life. Country musicians [[Terri Clark]], [[Emily West]], and [[Shelly Fairchild]] provided guest vocals on individual tracks, as did [[jazz]] singer [[Wendy Moten]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://musicrow.com/2022/05/ty-herndon-chronicles-journey-from-struggles-to-triumph-on-new-project-jacob/ | title=Ty Herndon Chronicles Journey From Struggles To Triumph On New Project 'Jacob' | publisher=[[MusicRow]] | date=May 12, 2022 | access-date=September 24, 2022 | author=Lorie Hollabaugh}}</ref> Herndon told [[Spin (magazine)|''Spin'']] that the album's title came from the account of [[Jacob wrestling with the angel]] in the [[Book of Genesis]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.spin.com/2022/08/ty-herndon-impact-jacob/ | title=How Ty Herndon Turned A Stint In Treatment Into A Collection Of No-Filler Comeback Tracks | publisher=Spin | date=August 11, 2022 | access-date=August 21, 2022 | author=Amanda Peukert}}</ref> This was followed in late 2022 by another single titled "God or the Gun", which was accompanied by a music video.<ref name="gun">{{cite web | url=https://people.com/country/ty-herndon-god-or-the-gun-music-video-premiere/ | title=Ty Herndon Says He Hopes 'God or the Gun' Inspires Fans to 'Choose the Light' — Watch the Video | publisher=People | date=July 13, 2022 | access-date=September 12, 2022}}</ref> The third single from the project was "Dents on a Chevy", a duet with Terri Clark.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://outsider.com/entertainment/music/country-music/ty-herndon-teams-with-terri-clark-new-track-dents-on-a-chevy/ | title=Ty Herndon Teams With Terri Clark for New Track 'Dents on a Chevy' | publisher=Outsider | date=March 10, 2023 | accessdate=March 18, 2023}}</ref>

==Musical style==
Herndon's singing voice has generally been met with critical favor. [[Stephen Thomas Erlewine]] of AllMusic wrote of Ty Herndon's musical style, "His earnest delivery was a good match for the kind of streamlined country he sang{{emdash}}music that didn't shun tradition but was aligned with the anthemic, rock-influenced arena-country pioneered by [[Garth Brooks]] at the dawn of the '90s."<ref name="allmusic"/> In a review of ''Lies I Told Myself'', Matt Bjorke of Roughstock wrote that "Ty's always been at his best on the ballads" and "sings his ass off showcasing a vocal many of the 'young guns' could learn from".<ref name="lies"/> Thom Jurek of AllMusic wrote that "Herndon has soul and plenty of it. You can hear the gospel in his voice, his love of the old country songs, but his delivery is thoroughly contemporary."<ref name="allmusic right"/>  An article from ''Music City News'' magazine re-published in the ''[[Asheville Citizen-Times]]'' said of Herndon, "there is a passion in his ballads, and in the case of...'I Want My Goodbye Back', an edgy emotional twist that sends listeners careening along with him".<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/199618806 | title=Jeff Carson building his reputation with 'Not on Your Love' and 'The Car' | work=Asheville Citizen-Times | date=March 15, 1996 | access-date=June 18, 2022 | pages=18C, 22C}}</ref> Dan MacIntosh described Herndon as having "straight-with-no-frills singing".<ref name="cst steam"/> Walter Allread wrote of Herndon on the same site, "Country music now resembles early Sixties American pop, with producers the real artists and singers merely interchangeable faces on record sleeves. As long as Ty Herndon's nice voice and face can front a hit, he's good for another 100,000 miles of touring and audio tape."<ref name="cst big hopes"/>

The lyrical content of his Epic albums was met with mixed reception. Michael McCall of ''New Country'' found some of the tracks on ''What Mattered Most'' "shallow", such as "In Your Face" and "Heart Half Empty".<ref name="mccall"/> Both ''Entertainment Weekly'' and AllMusic panned ''Living in a Moment'' for formulaic lyrics.<ref name="herndon moment"/><ref name="ew moment"/> In comparison, Herndon began writing songs in the 2010s; although he had not written previously, he thought that doing so would allow his albums to become more personal.<ref name="embraces"/>

== Personal life ==
In June 1995, Herndon was arrested in Fort Worth, Texas, at Gateway Park by an undercover male police officer. This officer alleged that Herndon [[indecent exposure|exposed]] himself.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ty Herndon arrested for indecent exposure|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1955&dat=19950616&id=ZolVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=dD8NAAAAIBAJ&pg=3816,233544|date=June 16, 1995|work=Reading Eagle (Pa.)|access-date=November 20, 2014}}</ref> When taken into custody, Herndon was also discovered to be in possession of [[methamphetamine]]. Herndon filed a plea bargain and was sentenced to community service and [[drug rehabilitation]], after which the charge of indecent exposure was dropped.<ref>{{cite news|last=Floyd|first=Jacquielynn|title=Singer Herndon given probation after felony drug arrest in FW; Exposure charge was factor in plea bargain, official says|newspaper=The Dallas Morning News|date=July 18, 1995}}</ref><ref name="allmusic"/>

In 2002, Herndon underwent a series of personal setbacks. Early in the year, he was robbed at gunpoint in [[Los Angeles]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1453284/herndon-held-up-in-la/ | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220618225827/http://www.cmt.com/news/1453284/herndon-held-up-in-la/ | url-status=dead | archive-date=June 18, 2022 | title=Herndon Held Up in L.A. | publisher=CMT | date=April 5, 2002 | access-date=June 18, 2022}}</ref> He also had a lawsuit filed against him by a California dentist claiming that Herndon had not paid for emergency dental work and another lawsuit from a former manager for breach of contract.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1484564/01232004/herndon_ty.jhtml |title=CMT.com : Ty Herndon : HOT TALK: Kenny Chesney Hit Based on Fact |access-date=February 18, 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080314235440/http://www.cmt.com/artists/news/1484564/01232004/herndon_ty.jhtml |archive-date=March 14, 2008 }}</ref> In addition, he relapsed into drug and alcohol addiction. This led to him experiencing depression and weight gain. After his friends noticed he had not left his apartment in several days, they flew him to Nashville, where he lived in his mother's basement for one month before re-entering rehabilitation. After completing this, he returned to performing in 2004.<ref name="gactv.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.gactv.com/gac/ar_artists_a-z/article/0,,GAC_26071_4751639,00.html|archive-url=https://archive.today/20130123183341/http://www.gactv.com/gac/ar_artists_a-z/article/0,,GAC_26071_4751639,00.html|title=Artists : Artists A to Z : Ty Herndon Biography: Great American Country|access-date=June 7, 2019|archive-date=January 23, 2013}}</ref> Herndon's addiction to methamphetamine resulted in a second relapse in 2020, at which point he was discovered in his apartment with both methamphetamine and [[Ambien]] in his possession.<ref name="sheeler"/> According to him, this was the result of trauma from his first experience with metamphetamines at age 20, at which point he was raped.<ref name="sheeler"/> This was an attempted [[suicide]], and would later serve as the inspiration behind his song "God or the Gun".<ref name="gun"/> Herndon successfully underwent drug rehabilitation a second time in late 2020-early 2021.<ref name="sheeler">{{cite web | url=https://people.com/country/ty-herndon-on-addiction-suicide-attempt-coming-out/ | title=Country Star Ty Herndon on Addiction, a Suicide Attempt and How Coming Out Saved His Life | publisher=[[People (magazine)|People]] | date=June 15, 2022 | access-date=June 18, 2022 | author=Jason Sheeler}}</ref> In addition to this, Herndon was diagnosed with [[bipolar disorder]] in 2021.<ref name="sheeler"/> In August 2022, Herndon began a podcast called Soundboard with Ty Herndon, in which he discusses his personal life and mental health. Guests on the podcast have included singers [[LeAnn Rimes]] and [[Michael Ray (singer)|Michael Ray]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://musicrow.com/2022/08/ty-herndon-talks-mental-health-on-new-soundboard-podcast/ | title=Ty Herndon Talks Mental Health On New 'Soundboard' Podcast | publisher=MusicRow | date=August 18, 2022 | access-date=August 21, 2022 | author=Lorie Hollabaugh}}</ref>

===Relationships and sexual orientation===
Herndon married Renee Posey on March 13, 1993. The couple lived in [[Dallas, Texas]], at the time, but held their wedding in Nashville.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/788966127/ | title=Posey-Herndon | work=San Angelo Standard-Times | date=April 4, 1993 | access-date=June 18, 2022 | pages=5E}}</ref> During the 1990s, Posey worked as a registered nurse.<ref name="rock"/> Following Herndon's 1995 arrest, his sexuality became a topic of interest within the country music industry, as many presumed Herndon to be gay. At the time, Herndon's manager told ''[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]]'' he did not know Herndon's orientation, but thought country music "was ready" for an artist to [[coming out|come out]] as gay.<ref>{{cite journal | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EmUEAAAAMBAJ&dq=%22ty+herndon%22&pg=PA71 | title=Midnight cowboy | journal=The Advocate | page=71 | date=July 25, 1995}}</ref> The editors of ''The Encyclopedia of Country Music'' wrote of the exposure incident that it "raised sexuality questions" within the genre, and that Herndon's continued commercial success throughout the rest of the 1990s indicated an unprecedented level of tolerance within the fandom.<ref name="encyclopedia">{{cite encyclopedia |entry=Ty Herndon | encyclopedia=The Encyclopedia of Country Music | publisher=Oxford University Press | access-date=June 18, 2022 |editor=Michael McCall |editor2=John Rumble |editor3=Paul Kingsbury |date=2012 | pages=237 | isbn=978-0-19-992083-9 |entry-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tLZz02EzmBYC&dq=%22ty+herndon%22&pg=PA237}}</ref> Herndon and Posey divorced in 2002.<ref name="gactv.com"/> 

Herndon came out as gay in a 2014 interview with ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'' magazine,<ref name="proud">{{cite web | url=https://people.com/country/country-star-ty-herndon-comes-out-as-gay/ | title=Country Star Ty Herndon: 'I'm an Out, Proud and Happy Gay Man' | publisher=People | date=November 20, 2014 | access-date=June 18, 2022 | author=Jeff Nelson}}</ref> thus becoming the first mainstream male country star to do so.<ref name="sheeler"/><ref name="opry"/> He stated that he had been in a gay relationship for several years at this point, and that his ex-wife and several close family members already knew.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Leopold|first1=Todd|title=Country star Ty Herndon comes out as gay|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/11/20/showbiz/celebrity-news-gossip/ty-herndon-gay/index.html|access-date=November 20, 2014|publisher=CNN|agency=[[Turner Broadcasting System]] ([[Time Warner]])|date=November 20, 2014|location=United States}}</ref> Herndon was partnered with his boyfriend Matt Collum for eleven years before the two amicably separated in 2021.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://people.com/country/ty-herndon-matt-collum-split-after-11-years/ | title=Ty Herndon and Boyfriend Matt Collum Split After '11 Beautiful Years Together' | publisher=People | date=October 27, 2021 | access-date=June 18, 2022 | author=Tomás Mier}}</ref> In relation to his coming out, Herndon re-issued "What Mattered Most" in June 2019 with the song's pronouns changed to reflect a gay relationship. This re-recording appeared on ''Got It Covered'', and Herndon commented that he wished he could have recorded the song in that fashion at the time of its original release.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/pride/8514976/ty-herndon-talks-what-mattered-most-reissue |title=Ty Herndon Talks 'What Mattered Most' Reissue, Says New Generation of Country Embraces 'Everyone' |website=Billboard.com |access-date=2020-04-14}}</ref> Many of the songs on ''House on Fire'', including the title track, are about the stigmas that Herndon felt he faced as a gay man in country music, typically a more conservative genre. He also credited conversations with country singer [[Chely Wright]], who came out as a lesbian in 2010, with giving him the confidence to come out.<ref name="embraces"/> Another inspiration to Herndon was hearing [[Carrie Underwood]]'s "[[So Small]]" on radio.<ref name="small"/> Herndon's announcement preceded the coming out of several other gay musicians in the genre, such as [[Billy Gilman]]. Herndon noted that his fan base was largely supportive of him after his announcement.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.nbcnews.com/feature/nbc-out/ty-herndon-risked-his-career-come-out-he-s-fighter-n684731 | title=Ty Herndon Risked His Career to Come Out, But He's a Fighter | publisher=[[NBC]] | date=November 16, 2016 | access-date=June 18, 2022}}</ref> Herndon and Wright have performed together at benefit concerts for [[GLAAD]] on multiple occasions.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.billboard.com/culture/pride/ty-herndon-what-mattered-most-new-pronouns-8514840/ | title=Ty Herndon Re-Releases Country Hit 'What Mattered Most' With New Pronouns: Watch | publisher=Billboard | date=June 6, 2019 | access-date=June 18, 2022 | author=Stephen Daw}}</ref> In 2016, Herndon and [[CMT (American TV channel)|CMT]] presenter Cody Alan founded the Concert for Love and Acceptance, an annual concert to support LGBT youth in Nashville.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://roughstock.com/news/2017/04/41715-ty-herndon-announces-2nd-concert-for-love-acceptance | title=Ty Herndon Announces 2nd Concert for Love & Acceptance | publisher=Roughstock | date=April 13, 2017 | access-date=June 18, 2022 | author=Matt Bjorke}}</ref> In February 2023, Herndon became engaged to Alex Schwartz, whom he had been dating for six months prior.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://people.com/country/ty-herndon-engaged-to-boyfriend-alex-after-six-months-of-dating/ | title=Ty Herndon Is Engaged to Boyfriend Alex After 6 Months of Dating: 'It Has Been an Amazing Journey' | publisher=People | date=February 10, 2023 | accessdate=February 10, 2023}}</ref> They married on August 27, 2023.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://people.com/ty-herndon-marries-alex-schwartz-tennessee-wedding-photos-exclusive-7852782 | title=Ty Herndon Marries Alex Schwartz in Scenic Tennessee Farm Wedding: All the Details! (Exclusive) | publisher=People | date=August 27, 2023 | accessdate=August 27, 2023 | author=Jordan Greene, Emily Strohm}}</ref>
